Award.AwardTitle: Adapting Socio-ecological Systems to Increased Climate Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this five-year project, Oklahoma Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) seeks to advance understanding of how socio-ecological systems can adapt sustainably to increased climate variability caused by a changing climate. This knowledge will be used to empower managers to effectively adapt socio-ecological systems to climate variability and educate Oklahomans about the expected consequences of regional environmental change. Three interlinked research focus areas are proposed to examine complex human, climate, and natural resource systems. These are: a socio-ecological observatory network; a socio-ecological forecasting system, and a decision support system. Each of the three components is linked with feedback loops, providing integration among the constituent parts. The major participants in this proposal are: Oklahoma State University (OSU), the University of Oklahoma (OU), the Samuel Roberts Noble Foundation (SRNF), and the University of Tulsa (TU). OSU and OU are the state?s public Ph.D. granting institutions serving 23,500 and 22,600 students respectively , TU is a Ph.D. granting private institution serving approximately 4,000 students and SRNF is an independent non-profit institute that moves science and innovation from the laboratory to agricultural producers. The project also involves additional collaborations with Langston University (LU), a historically black university that serves 3,000 students, four tribal colleges, state and federal agencies/laboratories, and K-12 schools.

Intellectual Merit
Oklahoma has been subject to many climate-related events that have caused significant economic hardship and damage. The proposed activities enable Oklahoma to examine socio-ecological feedback loops, to study the connections between different scales of analysis (e.g., community, landscape), and to consider whether proposed solutions for sustainability can be applied at levels where effective social or ecological changes can occur. Research activities support the development of decision support systems that provide information for stakeholders regarding their vulnerability and options to respond to an increasingly variable and changing climate. The majority of activities are focused on drought, complementing existing State activities within the areas of hydrology, ecology, and meteorological sciences.

Broader Impacts
Oklahoma EPSCoR develops research and education activities to engage a wide number of constituents. STEM activities are directed at providing research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, STEM activity kits for girls through the girl scouts of America, and summer internships among other activities. Some of these activities specifically recruite females, Native Americans, and other minorities, while K-12 activities focus on rural populations. Education pedagogy specialists will assist K-12 teachers in translating thematic science content into classroom lessons that are shared virtually across the state. The Oklahoma EPSCoR website and social media are used to provide a clearinghouse for information such as climate-related brochures, videos, and classroom resources, event information, and funding opportunities. The activities particularly focus on engaging Native Americans in both research and education. Tribal liaisons (federal, state, and tribal employees) and anthropologists will be engaged to ensure that research questions are inclusive of the views and needs of tribal environmental specialists. The activities strengthen areas noted to be important within the State?s Science and Technology Plan such as workforce training and development in the areas of agriculture, climate change and social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Oklahoma, the economy greatly depends on the extraction and utilization of natural resources. Predictable and increasing ecosystem services are needed to provide energy, food, fiber, freshwater, and clean air for a healthy human society. This is particularly true at regional, state, and local scales, where changes in climate variability and its expected patterns can overwhelm the resilience and robustness of existing systems. In Oklahoma, as in many semi-arid regions of the world, a highly variable climate and large precipitation gradient result in rapid transitions that creates a landscape that is highly vulnerable to climatic extremes. To develop sustainable natural resource supplies that support a vibrant economy with healthy and productive citizens, we need to significantly advance our understanding of how socioecological systems can adapt sustainably to increased climate variability caused by a changing climate. The multi-year drought in the southern Plains that started in 2013 has highlighted the very real risks and vulnerabilities that considerable variability in the climate imposes on socio-ecological systems. The project aimed to empower managers to effectively adapt socio-ecological systems to climate variability and change and to educate Oklahomans about regional environmental changes. To accomplish our vision and goals, we improved our research infrastructure, transforming Oklahoma’s capability to be nationally competitive in the increasingly important research area of coupled human and natural systems. We used an innovative research platform to center on a first-of-its-kind statewide tightly coupled human and natural systems observatory, with integrated measurement, modeling, and prediction capabilities and decision-support tools and systems.

 

We established a world class socio-ecological observatory to collect under-sampled observations of human and natural systems across different climates, land use, disturbance, and socio-economic environments. The observatory includes the Meso-Scale Integrated Socio-geographic Network (M-SISNet), a state-of-the-art statewide socio-ecological data frame that used address-based sampling frame that is geospatially linked to nearby Oklahoma Mesonet sites. M-SISNet group maintained full recruitment for the statewide panel of 1,500 respondents and collaborated with sociologists, geographers, and economists within and outside of the project in utilizing M-SISNet as a tool to augment research. Through the interactive M-SISNet website, which was visited over 5,950 times, full datasets have been downloaded over 315 times and survey codebooks have been downloaded more than 2,350 times. We built socio-ecological modeling and prediction system to integrate qualitative and quantitative data from socio-ecological observatories and to examine systematically insights from disciplinary and integrated perspectives.

 

We also developed a pilot decision-support system that provides researchers, educators, and practitioners the data, models, tools, and scenarios to explore and understand the social and ecological impacts of decisions related to a specific need through the state-wide water survey portal. The OK EPSCoR website, which was visited more than 112,300 times, hosts decision support tools developed through the project: OK Water Use calculator, Geospatial Model representing U.S. desalination plants, Geospatial Groundwater Visualization Models, OK Soil Moisture Map, OK Counties Social Vulnerability Fact Sheets, OK Social Vulnerability Validation Map, and Ethnographic Story Maps of Kiamichi, Cimarron River, Upper Washita-Caddo County, and North Canadian Watersheds. These tools will continue to be accessed and used in future research to evaluate competing mitigation and adaptation strategies. Key thresholds and feedbacks identified by our coupled human and natural systems approach were used to develop decision-support systems to enhance resilience of the socio-ecological systems to climate variability and climate change.

 

The project leveraged core strengths in weather-water-climate, environmental sociology, high-performance computing at OU and OSU, data assimilation, numerical modeling, remote sensing, agriculture, and terrestrial ecology; added new faculty, capabilities, and infrastructure, particularly in social sciences, coupled human and natural systems research, and ecological informatics; and significantly advanced the efforts to integrate these strengths around socioecological adaptation to climate change, with a particular focus on water availability.

 

The research was conducted by a cross-disciplinary and diverse team of researchers, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows across all of the major participating institutions (Oklahoma State University, University of Oklahoma, Noble Research Institute and University of Tulsa) in Oklahoma.

 

Our commitment to education and mentoring, from young students to junior faculty, resonates throughout our research and outreach and is elevated by the relevance of our research to current and projected future challenges to land and water resource management as a result of regional drought. This project’s outreach and education programs have reached over 113,175 Oklahomans during the entire project period; 60% of those participants were female and 31% were from an underrepresented minority group (URM). Our K-12 programs served over 61,950 students across the state; 69% were female and 34% URM. More than 1,975 K-12 educators received STEM materials and training (77% female, 14% URM). In the higher education category, over 8,150 individuals (53% female, 22% URM) were served through EPSCoR outreach programs; 69% of those participants were from PMU and minority-serving institutions.
